verses.textEn: Bride: <font color="#0000CC">May he kiss me with the kiss of his mouth.</font>
verses.textLa: Osculetur me osculo oris sui.
verses.notes: The bride is speaking about her desire for the groom. The pronoun ‘sui’ is singular masculine; it cannot be singular feminine; therefore, this is the bride speaking about the groom.

verses.textEn: Groom to Bride: <font color="#CC0000">So much better than wine are your breasts, fragranced with the finest perfumes.</font>
verses.textLa: Quia meliora sunt ubera tua vino, fragrantia unguentis optimis.
verses.notes: Now the groom is speaking about his bride’s breasts and perfume, which symbolize her feminine beauty, both outer and inner. Therefore, this must be the groom speaking about the bride. Although ‘unguentis’ is usually translated as ‘ointments,’ in this context it clearly refers to perfumes. In ancient times, oils and resins were used for their fragrant smell.

verses.textEn: Bride to Groom: <font color="#0000CC">Your name is oil that has been poured out; therefore, the maidens have loved you. Draw me forward.</font>
verses.textLa: Oleum effusum nomen tuum: ideo adolescentulæ dilexerunt te. Trahe me.
verses.notes: The Bride is speaking about her groom, saying that the maidens (or adolescent girls) are attracted to him, (they wish that they were marrying the groom, instead of the bride). She asks him to draw her to him.

verses.textEn: Chorus to Bride: <font color="#008800">We will run after you in the odor of your perfumes.</font>
verses.textLa: Post te curremus in odorem unguentorum tuorum.
verses.notes: This cannot be the bride speaking, because the speaker is plural. Also, the person they are running after is perfumed, so they must be running after the bride. Therefore, this is the chorus of maidens speaking. The Chorus is those adolescent girls mentioned in the verse above, who are attracted to the groom. They admire the bride; they wish that they were getting married in her place. As the bride is drawn to the groom, they are drawn by admiration of her to follow after her.

verses.textEn: Bride to Chorus: <font color="#0000CC">The king has led me into his storerooms.</font>
verses.textLa: Introduxit me rex in cellaria sua.
verses.notes: The chorus says that they will follow the bride, and the bride replies by saying where she is being led, i.e. where they will also go if they follow her: into the storerooms (including those of wine, as we find out later in the book). The groom, on the historical or literal level of meaning, is king Solomon.

verses.textEn: Chorus to Bride: <font color="#008800">We will exult and rejoice in you, remembering your breasts above wine.</font>
verses.textLa: Exultabimus et lætabimur in te, memores uberum tuorum super vinum.
verses.notes: The ‘we’ is the chorus speaking about the bride. They tell her that her breasts, symbolic of her inner feminine beauty, are better than the wine of the king’s storerooms.

verses.textEn: Groom to Bride: <font color="#CC0000">The righteous love you.</font>
verses.textLa: Recti diligunt te.
verses.notes: Now it is the groom’s turn to speak. The word ‘recti’ is nominative plural; so this is not the chorus saying ‘we’ love you, but the groom saying to the bride why they, the chorus, love her. This is not the bride speaking to the groom, because it follows after the chorus’ expression of admiration and love for the bride. Therefore, it is an explanation as to why the chorus of girls finds the bride so admirable: it is because they are maturing in righteousness and are therefore attracted to a woman who is more righteous than they are. The Bride’s feminine beauty, symbolized by her breasts, is the inner beauty of righteousness.

verses.textEn: Bride to Chorus: <font color="#0000CC">O daughters of Jerusalem: I am black, but shapely, like the tabernacles of Kedar, like the tents of Solomon.</font>
verses.textLa: Nigra sum, sed formosa, filiæ Ierusalem, sicut tabernacula Cedar, sicut pelles Salomonis.
verses.notes: In the historical level of meaning, the bride is dark-skinned and from Africa (a Sulamite, as we later learn). The Latin word ‘pelles’ is here used to refer to tents, or hangings in tents, made from animal skins. The tents of Kedar were literally black, made from black animal hair. This must be the bride speaking because the feminine form of the words ‘nigra’ and ‘formosa’ are used (both words have a masculine form which could have been used if this was the groom speaking).

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">Do not be concerned that I am dark, for the sun has changed my color.</font>
verses.textLa: Nolite me considerare quod fusca sim, quia decoloravit me sol.
verses.notes: The bride is speaking about herself, because the word 'fusca' in Latin is in the feminine, yet there is a masculine version of that same word which could have been used if the speaker were male. She says that the sun has changed her skin color, perhaps meaning, not that she herself used to have a light-colored skin, but that her ancestors developed dark skin from living in a hot and sunny climate (Africa).

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">The sons of my mother have fought against me. They have made me the keeper of the vineyards. My own vineyard I have not kept.</font>
verses.textLa: Filii matris meæ pugnaverunt contra me, posuerunt me custodem in vineis: vineam meam non custodivi.
verses.notes: The bride is speaking about herself, because the word ‘meae’ in Latin is in the feminine, yet there is a masculine version of that same word which could have been used if the speaker were male. So this is still the bride speaking; she tells how she was mistreated by the sons of her mother. In that culture and time period, a man might have more than one wife, so that the sons of her mother are children of the same father and mother as she has. They are her closest relatives, after her father and mother; yet they mistreated her.

verses.textEn: Bride to Groom: <font color="#0000CC">Reveal to me, you whom my soul loves, where you pasture, where you recline at midday, lest I begin to wander after the flocks of your companions.</font>
verses.textLa: Indica mihi, quem diligit anima mea, ubi pascas, ubi cubes in meridie, ne vagari incipiam post greges sodalium tuorum.
verses.notes: The bride speaks about her groom and his companions. The words for ‘your companions’ (sodalium tuorum) are masculine; therefore, she is speaking about him and his friends. Also, ‘quem’ is singular masculine, again indicating that she is speaking about him.

verses.textEn: Groom to Bride: <font color="#CC0000">If you yourself do not know, O most beautiful among women, then go out and follow after the steps of the flocks, and pasture your young goats beside the tabernacles of the shepherds.</font>
verses.textLa: Si ignoras te o pulcherrima inter mulieres, egredere, et abi post vestigia gregum, et pasce hœdos tuos iuxta tabernacula pastorum.
verses.notes: Now the groom speaks about his bride, who is most beautiful among women, asking her to seek to know him better by doing, not merely by words.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">O my love, I have compared you to my company of horsemen against the chariots of Pharaoh.</font>
verses.textLa: Equitatui meo in curribus Pharaonis assimilavi te amica mea.
verses.notes: The groom is still speaking, because ‘my love’ is feminine, so he is speaking about her. Also, he has of a company of soldiers with horses, so he must be male. The bride did not have a company of horsemen, for she was mistreated by her brothers and made to tend a vineyard. The company of horsemen the groom commands are not part of the chariots of Pharaoh, rather they are compared versus the chariots of Pharaoh, against whom they fight successfully. The groom is Solomon; these horsemen are his best.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">Your cheeks are beautiful, like those of a turtledove. Your neck is like a bejeweled collar.</font>
verses.textLa: Pulchræ sunt genæ tuæ sicut turturis: collum tuum sicut monilia.
verses.notes: The groom continues speaking; the comparison of cheeks to those of a dove must refer to a woman. The word ‘monilia’ has the sense of jewelry, but also of a collar worn as adornment.

verses.textEn: Chorus to Bride: <font color="#008800">We will fashion for you chains of gold, accented with reddened silver.</font>
verses.textLa: Murenulas aureas faciemus tibi, vermiculatas argento.
verses.notes: The chorus is indicated by the word ‘we;’ these adolescent girls would be close to marring age and would have already been taught various skills, such as weaving or making jewelry. Silver ore is a reddish color (rust/gray), often called ‘red silver ore.’ The term ‘vermiculatas argento’ refers to silver which has a reddish color, perhaps deliberately reddened with an alloy, to accent the gold. The use of the word ‘accented’ in the translation is based on the context and on the ‘at’ in ‘vermiculatas’ which has the sense of ‘provided with’ or ‘having.’ The word ‘vermiculum’ is found in the Latin text of the book of Exodus, referring to a reddish color used in making the tabernacle of the testimony.

verses.textEn: Bride to Chorus: <font color="#0000CC">While the king was taking his rest, my aromatic ointment sent forth its odor.</font>
verses.textLa: Dum esset rex in accubitu suo, nardus mea dedit odorem suum.
verses.notes: The word ‘nardus’ refers to a particular plant from whose roots is derived an aromatic oil used for perfume as well as medicine.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">My beloved is a bundle of myrrh to me. He shall abide between my breasts.</font>
verses.textLa: Fasciculus myrrhæ dilectus meus mihi, inter ubera mea commorabitur.
verses.notes: Myrrh is associated with death, as well as with healing; it was used in incense and perfumes and ointments.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">My beloved is a cluster of Cyprus grapes to me, in the vineyards of Engaddi.</font>
verses.textLa: Botrus Cypri dilectus meus mihi, in vineis Engaddi.
verses.notes: The bride is speaking; she refers to the groom as ‘my beloved’ which is masculine in Latin (dilectus meus). ‘Botrus Cypri’ refers to a cluster of grapes from Cyprus. The word ‘Cypri’ means Cyprus. The island of Cyprus has an ancient tradition of wine-making going back over four thousand years; their grapes and wine were renown, even in ancient times. The word Cypri does not refer to the cypress tree, except that the island was perhaps named after that tree. Botrus means ‘cluster of grapes,’ and this is also clear from the subsequent reference to a vineyard. Engaddi was a type of oasis, a town located where a warm spring was in ancient times, near the Dead Sea.

verses.textEn: Groom to Bride: <font color="#CC0000">Behold, you are beautiful, O my love. Behold, you are beautiful. Your eyes are those of a dove.</font>
verses.textLa: Ecce tu pulchra es amica mea, ecce tu pulchra es, oculi tui columbarum.
verses.notes: The groom speaks about his bride, using the feminine Latin words ‘mea amica.’

verses.textEn: Bride to Groom: <font color="#0000CC">Behold, you are handsome, O my beloved, and graceful. Our bed is flourishing.</font>
verses.textLa: Ecce tu pulcher es dilecte mi, et decorus. Lectulus noster floridus.
verses.notes: She is speaking about him, using the masculine ‘dilecte mi’ and ‘decorus.’ Now, for the first time, she uses ‘our’ (a plural pronoun) to refer to herself and the groom united in love.

verses.textEn: Groom to Bride: <font color="#CC0000">The timbers of our houses are of cedar; our ceilings are of cypress.</font>
verses.textLa: Tigna domorum nostrarum cedrina, laquearia nostra cypressina.
verses.notes: Now it is his turn to speak; he speaks about how the house was built. Notice that the use of the word ‘cypressina’ to mean ‘of cypress’ differs substantially from the previous verse using ‘cypri’ to mean ‘of Cyprus’.

verses.textEn: Bride: <font color="#0000CC">I am a flower of the open field and a lily of the steep valleys.</font>
verses.textLa: Ego flos campi, et lilium convallium.
verses.notes: She describes herself as a flower, so this cannot be him speaking. The word ‘campi’ is not synonymous with ‘field’; it tends more toward the meaning of a wide open space. The prefix ‘con’ intensifies the meaning of the world, so that the valley is not just any valley, but a steep (inaccessible) one.

verses.textEn: Groom: <font color="#CC0000">Like a lily among the thorns, so is my loved one among the daughters.</font>
verses.textLa: Sicut lilium inter spinas, sic amica mea inter filias.
verses.notes: He uses the feminine form ‘amica’ to speak about her, so this is the groom speaking.

verses.textEn: Bride to Chorus: <font color="#0000CC">Like an apple tree among the trees of the forest, so is my beloved among the sons. I sat beneath the shadow of the one whom I desired, and his fruit was sweet to my palate.</font>
verses.textLa: Sicut malus inter ligna silvarum, sic dilectus meus inter filios. Sub umbra illius quem desideraveram, sedi: et fructus eius dulcis gutturi meo.
verses.notes: She refers to him by the masculine word ‘dilectus’ and says that he is better than his male peers, ‘filios’. She also uses the masculine: “illius quem.” He is figuratively the tree, so she is the one sitting under it.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">He brought me into the storeroom of wine. He set charity in order within me.</font>
verses.textLa: Introduxit me in cellam vinariam, ordinavit in me charitatem.
verses.notes: This verse is her speaking, continuing the previous idea in chapter 1 of king Solomon (i.e. the groom) bringing her into his storeroom of wine.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">Prop me up with flowers. Close me in with apples. For I languish through love.</font>
verses.textLa: Fulcite me floribus, stipate me malis: quia amore langueo.
verses.notes: Still the bride is speaking; this is the language of a woman, talking about being propped up with flowers and languishing due to love. Her language is figurative, not literal.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">His left hand is under my head, and his right hand shall embrace me.</font>
verses.textLa: Læva eius sub capite meo, et dextera illius amplexabitur me.
verses.notes: She continues, speaking about his embrace. Again, it pertains to a woman to be embraced, and to a man to do the embracing. Also, if it were her right hand embracing, she would not be asleep, but we learn that she is asleep in the next verse, so he is the one embracing her.

verses.textEn: Groom to Chorus: <font color="#CC0000">I bind you by oath, O daughters of Jerusalem, by the does and the stags of the open field, not to disturb or awaken the beloved, even for as long as she wills.</font>
verses.textLa: Adiuro vos filiæ Ierusalem per capreas, cervosque camporum, ne suscitetis, neque evigilare faciatis dilectam, quoadusque ipsa velit.
verses.notes: He now speaks to her peers, the other daughters of Jerusalem, asking them not to wake his beloved (‘dilectam’ is the feminine form of the word), until she (ipsa, feminine) wills.

verses.textEn: Bride to Chorus: <font color="#0000CC">The voice of my beloved! Behold, he arrives leaping along the mountains, jumping across the hills.</font>
verses.textLa: Vox dilecti mei, ecce iste venit saliens in montibus, transiliens colles:
verses.notes: The word ‘dilectus’ (beloved) is masculine, so she is speaking about him.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">My beloved is like a doe and like a young stag.</font>
verses.textLa: similis est dilectus meus capreæ, hinnuloque cervorum.
verses.notes: She speaks about him using the masculine ‘dilectus.’

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">Lo, he stands beyond our wall, gazing through the windows, watching through the lattices.</font>
verses.textLa: En ipse stat post parietem nostrum respiciens per fenestras, prospiciens per cancellos.
verses.notes: She speaks about him using the masculine ‘ipse.’

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">Lo, my beloved speaks to me:</font>
verses.textLa: En dilectus meus loquitur mihi:
verses.notes: She speaks about him using the masculine ‘dilectus.’ She is attentive to his words.

verses.textEn: Groom to Bride: <font color="#CC0000">Rise up, quickly, my love, my dove, my shapely one, and advance.</font>
verses.textLa: Surge, propera amica mea, columba mea, formosa mea, et veni.
verses.notes: He calls her by several feminine terms: ‘amica’ (love or loved one), ‘columba’ (dove), ‘formosa’ (shapely one) and he calls her to come forward.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">For winter has now past; the rain has decreased and gone away.</font>
verses.textLa: Iam enim hiems transiit, imber abiit, et recessit.
verses.notes: He explains why she should rise up and advance, continuing from the previous sentence. It is now springtime, a good time for traveling, or for growth. Winter is the rainy season in the Holy Land.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">The flowers have appeared in our land; the time for pruning has arrived. The voice of the turtledove has been heard in our land.</font>
verses.textLa: Flores apparuerunt in terra nostra, tempus putationis advenit: vox turturis audita est in terra nostra:
verses.notes: He continues the previous description, about the arrival of spring, which is a figure of blossoming love.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">The fig tree has brought forth its green figs; the flowering vines bestow their odor. Rise up, my love, my brilliant one, and advance.</font>
verses.textLa: ficus protulit grossos suos: vineæ florentes dederunt odorem suum. Surge, amica mea, speciosa mea, et veni:
verses.notes: He continues the previous description and he then refers to her by the feminine ‘amica’ and ‘speciosa.’ Again, spring is referred to as a time of opportunity.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">My dove in the clefts of the rock, in the hollows of the wall, reveal to me your face. Let your voice sound in my ears. For your voice is sweet, and your face is graceful.</font>
verses.textLa: columba mea in foraminibus petræ, in caverna maceriæ, ostende mihi faciem tuam, sonet vox tua in auribus meis: vox enim tua dulcis, et facies tua decora.
verses.notes: He refers to her as being like a dove and he uses the feminine form ‘decora.’ She is hidden, but he hears and recognizes her voice. He can find her.

verses.textEn: Chorus to Groom and Bride: <font color="#008800">Capture for us the little foxes, which are tearing down the vines; for our vineyard has flourished.</font>
verses.textLa: Capite nobis vulpes parvulas, quæ demoliuntur vineas: nam vinea nostra floruit.
verses.notes: The chorus asks the Groom and Bride to help them with their vineyard.

verses.textEn: Bride to Chorus: <font color="#0000CC">My beloved is for me, and I am for him. He pastures among the lilies, until the day rises and the shadows decline.</font>
verses.textLa: Dilectus meus mihi, et ego illi, qui pascitur inter lilia donec aspiret dies, et inclinentur umbræ.
verses.notes: She speaks about him using the masculine ‘dilectus’. She again mentions, as in a previous verse, that he pastures among lilies until midday.

verses.textEn: Bride to Groom: <font color="#0000CC">Return, O my beloved. Be like a doe and like a young stag upon the mountains of Bether.</font>
verses.textLa: Revertere: similis esto, dilecte mi, capreæ, hinnuloque cervorum super montes Bether.
verses.notes: She calls him by the masculine ‘dilecte’ and she again compares him to the doe and stag. She speaks as if to him, even though he is absent.

verses.textEn: Bride: <font color="#0000CC">On my bed, throughout the night, I sought him whom my soul loves. I sought him, and did not find him.</font>
verses.textLa: In lectulo meo per noctes quæsivi quem diligit anima mea: quæsivi illum, et non inveni.
verses.notes: She uses the masculine ‘quem’ and ‘illum’, so this is her speaking to him.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">I will rise up, and I will circle through the city. Through the side streets and thoroughfares, I will seek him whom my soul loves. I sought him, and did not find him.</font>
verses.textLa: Surgam, et circuibo civitatem: per vicos et plateas quæram quem diligit anima mea: quæsivi illum, et non inveni.
verses.notes: She uses the masculine ‘quem’ and ‘illum’. She continues from the previous verse.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">The watchers who guard the city found me: “Have you seen him whom my soul loves?”</font>
verses.textLa: Invenerunt me vigiles, qui custodiunt civitatem: Num quem diligit anima mea, vidistis?
verses.notes: She continues from the previous verse. The word ‘vigiles’ is rendered ‘watchers’ rather than ‘watchmen’ because, in one level of meaning, the watchers are the holy Angels.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">When I had passed by them a little, I found him whom my soul loves. I held him, and would not release him, until I would bring him into my mother’s house, and into the chamber of her who bore me.</font>
verses.textLa: Paululum cum pertransissem eos, inveni quem diligit anima mea: tenui eum, nec dimittam donec introducam illum in domum matris meæ, et in cubiculum genetricis meæ.
verses.notes: She uses the masculine ‘quem’, ‘eum’, and ‘illum.’ She continues from the previous verse. Therefore, this is the Bride speaking again.

verses.textEn: Groom to Chorus: <font color="#CC0000">I bind you by oath, O daughters of Jerusalem, by the does and the stags of the open field, not to disturb or awaken the beloved, until she wills.</font>
verses.textLa: Adiuro vos filiæ Ierusalem per capreas, cervosque camporum, ne suscitetis, neque evigilare faciatis dilectam donec ipsa velit.
verses.notes: Now he is speaking again to her peers, the daughters of Jerusalem, and he refers to her as ‘ipsa’ in the feminine, therefore, this is the groom speaking.

verses.textEn: Chorus to Groom: <font color="#008800">Who is she, who ascends through the desert, like a staff of smoke from the aromatics of myrrh, and frankincense, and every powder of the perfumer?</font>
verses.textLa: Quæ est ista, quæ ascendit per desertum sicut virgula fumi ex aromatibus myrrhæ, et thuris, et universi pulveris pigmentarii?
verses.notes: This cannot be the bride speaking, because she would speak about herself in the first person. And it cannot be the groom, because he is more knowledgeable about his bride than the chorus. So it must be the chorus, inquiring so as to understand the bride even better.

verses.textEn: Chorus to Bride: <font color="#008800">Lo, sixty strong ones, out of all the strongest in Israel, stand watch at the bed of Solomon,</font>
verses.textLa: En lectulum Salomonis sexaginta fortes ambiunt ex fortissimis Israel:
verses.notes: After asking about the bride to be, the chorus notes that Solomon is disquieted on his bed, despite being surrounded by many soldiers, because he is anxious for her to arrive. Who is she who can disquiet a king?

verses.textEn: <font color="#008800">all holding swords and well-trained in warfare, each one’s weapon upon his thigh, because of fears in the night.</font>
verses.textLa: omnes tenentes gladios, et ad bella doctissimi: uniuscuiusque ensis super femur suum propter timores nocturnos.
verses.notes: There are four watches to the night, so the 60 soldiers guarding Solomon served 15 soldiers for each watch of the night. The daughters of Jerusalem note that all the worldly power of Solomon does not prevent one from fears in the night. This is a continuation of the previous question ‘who is she’? In other words, who is she who can disquiet the king on his bed? So this must be the chorus speaking.

verses.textEn: Bride to Chorus: <font color="#0000CC">King Solomon made himself a portable throne from the wood of Lebanon.</font>
verses.textLa: Ferculum fecit sibi rex Salomon de lignis Libani:
verses.notes: The Chorus asks the bride about the groom, noting he is disquiet on his bed. The bride replies to the Chorus, speaking about the dignity of Solomon on his throne. She understands him better than the chorus, so they are the one’s inquiring and she is the one answering. The phrasing ‘portable throne’ is from the original Douai Bible.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">He made its columns of silver, the reclining place of gold, the ascent of purple; the middle he covered well, out of charity for the daughters of Jerusalem.</font>
verses.textLa: columnas eius fecit argenteas, reclinatorium aureum, ascensum purpureum: media charitate constravit propter filias Ierusalem:
verses.notes: The middle was not just ‘stravit,’ covered; it was ‘constravit,’ well-covered. The prefix ‘con’ intensifies the meaning of the word. It was well-covered, so that the daughters of Jerusalem would not see all of the king’s figure and desire him. The bride notes the chastity and charity of the king.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">O daughters of Zion, go forth and see king Solomon with the diadem with which his mother crowned him, on the day of his espousal, on the day of the rejoicing of his heart.</font>
verses.textLa: Egredimini et videte filiæ Sion regem Salomonem in diademate, quo coronavit illum mater sua in die desponsationis illius, et in die lætitiæ cordis eius.
verses.notes: Now the bride tells the daughters to go to the king to see him in person. She talks about his mother and his wedding day. This is the manner of speech of a woman: talking about his mother and the rejoicing of his heart at his espousal.

verses.textEn: Groom to Bride: <font color="#CC0000">How beautiful you are, my love, how beautiful you are! Your eyes are those of a dove, except for what is hidden within. Your hair is like flocks of goats, which ascend along the mountain of Gilead.</font>
verses.textLa: Quam pulchra es amica mea, quam pulchra es! Oculi tui columbarum, absque eo, quod intrinsecus latet. Capilli tui sicut greges caprarum, quæ ascenderunt de monte Galaad.
verses.notes: If one translates ‘ascenderunt de’ in an overly literal manner, it would seem to say ‘ascend from.’ But the word ‘de’ actually has a broader range of meaning than the English word ‘from.’ The flock is going higher up the mountain, but they are not ascending as quickly and directly as they could, nor are they going all the way to the top, so they ‘ascend along.’

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">Your teeth are like flocks of shorn sheep, which ascend from the washing, each one with its identical twin, and not one among them is barren.</font>
verses.textLa: Dentes tui sicut greges tonsarum, quæ ascenderunt de lavacro, omnes gemellis fœtibus, et sterilis non est inter eas.
verses.notes: The groom describes the beauty of his bride; her outer beauty symbolizes her inner beauty.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">Your lips are like a scarlet ribbon, and your eloquence is sweetness. Like a piece of pomegranate, so are your cheeks, except for what is hidden within.</font>
verses.textLa: Sicut vitta coccinea, labia tua: et eloquium tuum, dulce. Sicut fragmen mali Punici, ita genæ tuæ, absque eo, quod intrinsecus latet.
verses.notes: The groom knows that her outer beauty in one sense reveals, and in another sense hides, her inner beauty.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">Your neck is like the tower of David, which was built with ramparts: a thousand shields are hanging from it, all the armor of the strong.</font>
verses.textLa: Sicut turris David collum tuum, quæ ædificata est cum propugnaculis: mille clypei pendant ex ea, omnis armatura fortium.
verses.notes: The groom describes his bride using the metaphor of a fortress of war.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">Your two breasts are like two young does, twins that pasture among the lilies.</font>
verses.textLa: Duo ubera tua, sicut duo hinnuli capreæ gemelli, qui pascuntur in liliis,
verses.notes: The groom describes his bride’s exterior beauty, but her feminine beauty is symbolic of her interior beauty. The expression ‘pasture among the lilies’ shows her peacefulness and holiness. The lilies are the Saints.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">Until the day rises and the shadows decline, I will go to the mountain of myrrh and to the hill of frankincense.</font>
verses.textLa: donec aspiret dies, et inclinentur umbræ, vadam ad montem myrrhæ, et ad collem thuris.
verses.notes: The groom uses the same wording previously used by his bride, except that she said he would act until the day rises and the shadows decline, whereas he now says ‘I will’ act until the day rises and the shadows decline. So this must be the groom speaking.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">You are totally beautiful, my love, and there is no blemish in you.</font>
verses.textLa: Tota pulchra es amica mea, et macula non est in te.
verses.notes: The groom finds no fault in his bride, his love.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">Advance from Lebanon, my spouse, advance from Lebanon, advance. You shall be crowned at the head of Amana, near the summit of Senir and Hermon, by the dens of lions, by the mountains of leopards.</font>
verses.textLa: Veni de Libano sponsa mea, veni de Libano, veni: coronaberis de capite Amana, de Sanir et Hermon, de cubilibus leonum, de montibus pardorum.
verses.notes: The word spouse (‘sponsa’) is feminine, so this is the groom speaking about his bride. The groom will exalt his humble bride, who formerly tended to vineyards and was mistreated by her brothers; he will crown her near the tops of mountains, away from the habitations of men.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">You have wounded my heart, my sister, my spouse. You have wounded my heart with one look of your eyes, and with one lock of hair on your neck.</font>
verses.textLa: Vulnerasti cor meum soror mea sponsa, vulnerasti cor meum in uno oculorum tuorum, et in uno crine colli tui.
verses.notes: The phrase ‘uno crine colli tui’ does not literally refer to a hair growing out of her neck; rather it refers to a lock or tress of hair resting on her neck.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">How beautiful are your breasts, my sister, my spouse! Your breasts are more beautiful than wine, and the fragrance of your ointments is above all aromatic oils.</font>
verses.textLa: Quam pulchræ sunt mammæ tuæ soror mea sponsa! Pulchriora sunt ubera tua vino, et odor unguentorum tuorum super omnia aromata.
verses.notes: Aromatics are such because they contain various kinds of oils. The groom is extolling his brides exterior beauty, which is symbolic of her inner beauty.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">Your lips, my spouse, are a dripping honeycomb; honey and milk are under your tongue. And the fragrance of your garments is like the odor of frankincense.</font>
verses.textLa: Favus distillans labia tua sponsa, mel et lac sub lingua tua: et odor vestimentorum tuorum sicut odor thuris.
verses.notes: The groom admires the words of his spouse (‘sponsa’), using the metaphors of honey and milk. Even the fragrance of her garments is admirable, which indicates symbolically the extent of her inner beauty.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">An enclosed garden is my sister, my spouse: an enclosed garden, a sealed fountain.</font>
verses.textLa: Hortus conclusus soror mea sponsa, hortus conclusus, fons signatus.
verses.notes: The groom extols the virginity and general faithfulness of his spouse; the garden of her body and her soul are pure and unspoiled.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">You send forth a paradise of pomegranates along with the fruits of the orchard: Cypress grapes, with aromatic oil;</font>
verses.textLa: Emissiones tuæ paradisus malorum Punicorum cum pomorum fructibus. Cypri cum nardo,
verses.notes: The phrase ‘malorum punicorum’ refers to Punician ‘apples,’ i.e. pomegranates. Again, the term ‘Cypri’ in the context of fruits of a garden refers to Cypress grapes. (These grapes were valued above other grapes because of the renown of the vineyards and wines of Cyprus.) The word ‘nardo’ is translated as ‘aromatic oil’ because that plant was used to make aromatic oil, and because ‘nard’ or ‘spikenard’ is unrecognizable to most readers.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">aromatic oil and saffron; sweet cane and cinnamon, with all the trees of Lebanon; myrrh and aloe, with all the best ointments.</font>
verses.textLa: nardus et crocus, fistula et cinnamomum cum universis lignis Libani, myrrha et aloe cum omnibus primis unguentis.
verses.notes: The trees of Lebanon produced some of the best wood of Biblical times. Ointments were used as perfumes, but also as remedies for various ailments.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">The fountain of the gardens is a well of living waters, which flow forcefully from Lebanon.</font>
verses.textLa: Fons hortorum: puteus aquarum viventium, quæ fluunt impetu de Libano.
verses.notes: The groom uses the metaphor of a well-watered garden to describe his bride. The term ‘living waters’ refers to flowing clean water, as opposed to stagnant and contaminated water.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">Rise up, north wind, and advance, south wind. Send a breeze through my garden, and carry its aromatic scents.</font>
verses.textLa: Surge Aquilo, et veni Auster, perfla hortum meum, et fluant aromata illius.
verses.notes: The groom uses this metaphor to say that he wants his bride to be appreciated for her inner and outer beauty far and wide, to the north and the south.

verses.textEn: Bride: <font color="#0000CC">May my beloved enter into his garden, and eat the fruit of his apple trees.</font>
verses.textLa: Veniat dilectus meus in hortum suum, et comedat fructum pomorum suorum.
verses.notes: The bride welcomes the groom and wants him to take refreshment in his garden. The word ‘dilectus’ is in the masculine, so this is the bride speaking about the groom.

verses.textEn: Groom to Bride: <font color="#CC0000">I have arrived in my garden, O my sister, my spouse. I have harvested my myrrh, with my aromatic oils. I have eaten the honeycomb with my honey. I have drunk my wine with my milk. Eat, O friends, and drink, and be inebriated, O most beloved.</font>
verses.textLa: Veni in hortum meum soror mea sponsa: messui myrrham meam cum aromatibus meis: comedi favum cum melle meo, bibi vinum meum cum lacte meo: comedite amici, et bibite, et inebriamini charissimi.
verses.notes: The groom has arrived in his garden and has taken refreshment there. He also invites all his friends and his beloved bride to take refreshment there also.

verses.textEn: Bride: <font color="#0000CC">I sleep, yet my heart watches.</font> The voice of my beloved knocking:
verses.textLa: Ego dormio, et cor meum vigilat: vox dilecti mei pulsantis:
verses.notes: The bride is so anxious for the arrival of the groom, that her heart keeps watch, even while she is asleep.

verses.textEn: Groom to Bride: <font color="#CC0000">Open to me, my sister, my love, my dove, my immaculate one. For my head is full of dew, and the locks of my hair are full of the drops of the night.</font>
verses.textLa: Aperi mihi soror mea, amica mea, columba mea, immaculata mea: quia caput meum plenum est rore, et cincinni mei guttis noctium.
verses.notes: The groom asks the bride to let him in. He extols her purity and her beauty. It is night and he is suffering because of the night.

verses.textEn: Bride: <font color="#0000CC">I have taken off my tunic; how shall I be clothed in it? I have washed my feet; how shall I spoil them?</font>
verses.textLa: Expoliavi me tunica mea, quomodo induar illa? Lavi pedes meos, quomodo inquinabo illos?
verses.notes: The bride is reluctant to get up and to get dressed; she is reluctant to dirty her feet.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">My beloved put his hand through the window, and my inner self was moved by his touch.</font>
verses.textLa: Dilectus meus misit manum suam per foramen, et venter meus intremuit ad tactum eius.
verses.notes: At the first sign of the arrival of her beloved, at the first glimpse of him, she is moved to her inmost being. She watches for him through the window, and at the first sign of him, she is deeply moved.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">I rose up in order to open to my beloved. My hands dripped with myrrh, and my fingers were full of the finest myrrh.</font>
verses.textLa: Surrexi, ut aperirem dilecto meo: manus meæ stillaverunt myrrham, et digiti mei pleni myrrha probatissima.
verses.notes: The bride gets up to let her beloved in; her hands are covered with myrrh (used as an ointment for its fragrance and healthful properties).

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">I opened the bolt of my door to my beloved. But he had turned aside and had gone away. My soul melted when he spoke. I sought him, and did not find him. I called, and he did not answer me.</font>
verses.textLa: Pessulum ostii mei aperui dilecto meo: at ille declinaverat, atque transierat. Anima mea liquefacta est, ut locutus est: quæsivi, et non inveni illum: vocavi, et non respondit mihi.
verses.notes: The groom departs unexpectedly. The bride seeks him and calls to him, but he does not answer. She does not understand why he has departed.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">The keepers who circulate through the city found me. They struck me, and wounded me. The keepers of the walls took my veil away from me.</font>
verses.textLa: Invenerunt me custodes qui circumeunt civitatem: percusserunt me, et vulneraverunt me: tulerunt pallium meum mihi custodes murorum.
verses.notes: The guardians of the city, who circulate through its streets, come across the bride. They strike her because she is out late at night, wandering the streets, and they mistake her for an intruder in the city, or a thief. They remove her veil, with which she shielded her face from the cold and damp of the night, in order to identify her.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">I bind you by oath, O daughters of Jerusalem, if you find my beloved, announce to him that I languish through love.</font>
verses.textLa: Adiuro vos filiæ Ierusalem, si inveneritis dilectum meum, ut nuncietis ei quia amore langueo.
verses.notes: The bride seeks the help of other women of the city, to find her beloved. She uses the masculine ‘dilectum,’ so this is the bride speaking about the groom.

verses.textEn: Chorus to Bride: <font color="#008800">What kind of beloved is your beloved, O most beautiful among women? What kind of beloved is your beloved, so that you would bind us by oath?</font>
verses.textLa: Qualis est dilectus tuus ex dilecto, o pulcherrima mulierum? Qualis est dilectus tuus ex dilecto, quia sic adiurasti nos?
verses.notes: The women inquire about the groom. They know that she loves him, but they do not fully understand why.

verses.textEn: Bride: <font color="#0000CC">My beloved is white and ruddy, elect among thousands.</font>
verses.textLa: Dilectus meus candidus et rubicundus, electus ex millibus.
verses.notes: The word ‘candidus’ can also mean radiant, or innocent, or pure. The word ‘rubicundus’ could also be translated as ‘reddened.’ The bride describes the groom as white, whereas she described herself previously as black.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">His head is like the finest gold. His locks are like the heights of palm trees, and as black as a raven.</font>
verses.textLa: Caput eius aurum optimum: Comæ eius sicut elatæ palmarum, nigræ quasi corvus.
verses.notes: The bride describes the appearance of the groom, but her description reveals her insights into his inner self. The gold of his head represents his trustworthy leadership and his pure love.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">His eyes are like doves, which have been washed with milk over rivulets of waters, and which reside near plentiful streams.</font>
verses.textLa: Oculi eius sicut columbæ super rivulos aquarum, quæ lacte sunt lotæ, et resident iuxta fluenta plenissima.
verses.notes: His eyes are peaceful; they show his mildness and generosity. A number of Old Testament rituals involved ‘living waters,’ i.e. running waters, similar to this verse.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">His cheeks are like a courtyard of aromatic plants, sown by perfumers. His lips are like lilies, dripping with the best myrrh.</font>
verses.textLa: Genæ illius sicut areolæ aromatum consitæ a pigmentariis. Labia eius lilia distillantia myrrham primam.
verses.notes: The groom is compared to a garden of plants used to produce perfumes, incense, and medicinal remedies. Perfumers would prepare various ointments, which were healthful as well as fragrant.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">His hands are smoothed gold, full of hyacinths. His abdomen is ivory, accented with sapphires.</font>
verses.textLa: Manus illius tornatiles aureæ, plenæ hyacinthis. Venter eius eburneus, distinctus sapphiris.
verses.notes: The word ‘tornatiles’ refers to gold that has been worked, to smooth and shape it. The brides description of him is increasingly metaphorical, because as she considers what she knows about his exterior, she begins to understand his inner self increasingly well.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">His legs are columns of marble, which have been established over bases of gold. His appearance is like that of Lebanon, elect like the cedars.</font>
verses.textLa: Crura illius columnæ marmoreæ, quæ fundatæ sunt super bases aureas. Species eius ut Libani, electus ut cedri.
verses.notes: The cedars of Lebanon were once among the greatest forests in the known world. The wood of their cedars was among the finest wood in the world.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">His throat is most sweet, and he is entirely desirable. Such is my beloved, and he is my friend, O daughters of Jerusalem.</font>
verses.textLa: Guttur illius suavissimum, et totus desiderabilis: talis est dilectus meus, et ipse est amicus meus, filiæ Ierusalem.
verses.notes: The bride realizes the depth of her love for the groom by meditating on his appearance and his inner qualities. She realizes he is both a friend and a love.

verses.textEn: Chorus to Bride: <font color="#008800">Where has your beloved gone, O most beautiful among women? To where has your beloved turned aside, so that we may seek him with you?</font>
verses.textLa: Quo abiit dilectus tuus o pulcherrima mulierum? Quo declinavit dilectus tuus, et quæremus eum tecum?
verses.notes: After hearing her loving description of him, the chorus (maidens or adolescent girls) also begins to love him and seek him.

verses.textEn: Bride: <font color="#0000CC">My beloved has descended to his garden, to the courtyard of aromatic plants, in order to pasture in the gardens and gather the lilies.</font>
verses.textLa: Dilectus meus descendit in hortum suum ad areolam aromatum, ut pascatur in hortis, et lilia colligat.
verses.notes: Aromatic plants were used as incense in worship, as perfumes, and as medicinal ointments. The groom has left her to descend to his garden. Formerly, she wondered why he left; now she understands why.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">I am for my beloved, and my beloved is for me. He pastures among the lilies.</font>
verses.textLa: Ego dilecto meo, et dilectus meus mihi, qui pascitur inter lilia.
verses.notes: The groom and bride have been getting to know one another better, and now they have reached a point where they are dedicated to one another. Again the bride describes the groom as pasturing among lilies. The lily is a delicate flower, so a pasture with lilies in it must be a mild and verdant pasture, not a harsh land.

verses.textEn: Groom to Bride: <font color="#CC0000">My love, you are beautiful: sweet and graceful, like Jerusalem; terrible, like an army in battle array.</font>
verses.textLa: Pulchra es amica mea, suavis, et decora sicut Ierusalem: terribilis ut castrorum acies ordinata.
verses.notes: He again uses imagery from war and battles to describe his bride; these are the metaphors that he understands. The word ‘amica’ is feminine, so this is the groom describing the bride.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">Avert your eyes from me, for they have caused me to fly away. Your hair is like a flock of goats, which have appeared out of Gilead.</font>
verses.textLa: Averte oculos tuos a me, quia ipsi me avolare fecerunt. Capilli tui sicut grex caprarum, quæ apparuerunt de Galaad.
verses.notes: This verse must be the groom speaking, because he now explains why earlier he fled. He again compares the tresses of her hair to a flock of goats on a mountain side.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">Your teeth are like a flock of sheep, which have ascended from the washing, each one with its identical twin, and not one among them is barren.</font>
verses.textLa: Dentes tui sicut grex ovium, quæ ascenderunt de lavacro, omnes gemellis fœtibus, et sterilis non est in eis.
verses.notes: The groom again contemplates the exterior beauty of the bride, which is symbolic of her inner beauty.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">Like the skin of a pomegranate, so are your cheeks, except for your hiddenness.</font>
verses.textLa: Sicut cortex mali Punici, sic genæ tuæ absque occultis tuis.
verses.notes: The groom realizes that the exterior beauty of the bride both reveals and hides her inner beauty. Her inner beauty is so great that it can never be completely expressed by her outer beauty.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">There are sixty queens, and eighty concubines, and maidens without number.</font>
verses.textLa: Sexaginta sunt reginæ, et octoginta concubinæ, et adolescentularum non est numerus.
verses.notes: There are many queens and concubines and maidens (waiting to become queens or concubines), but none can compare to the bride. The queens signify wives, the concubines symbolize those who have relations outside of marriage, the maidens symbolize those who remain chaste outside of marriage, including those who take vows.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">One is my dove, my perfect one. One is her mother; elect is she who bore her. The daughters saw her, and they proclaimed her most blessed. The queens and concubines saw her, and they praised her.</font>
verses.textLa: Una est columba mea, perfecta mea, una est matris suæ, electa genetrici suæ. Viderunt eam filiæ, et beatissimam prædicaverunt: reginæ et concubinæ, et laudaverunt eam.
verses.notes: The groom extols not only his bride, but also her mother, who bore and raised her, and those maidens who recognized her as a model for them to imitate. Even the queens and concubines of Solomon praised her.

verses.textEn: Chorus to Groom: <font color="#008800">Who is she, who advances like the rising dawn, as beautiful as the moon, as elect as the sun, as terrible as an army in battle array?</font>
verses.textLa: Quæ est ista, quæ progreditur quasi aurora consurgens, pulchra ut luna, electa ut sol, terribilis ut castrorum acies ordinata?
verses.notes: The maidens seek further knowledge of the bride, whom they admire and seek to imitate and follow, from the groom.

verses.textEn: Bride: <font color="#0000CC">I descended to the garden of nuts, in order to see the fruits of the steep valleys, and to examine whether the vineyard had flourished and the pomegranates had produced buds.</font>
verses.textLa: Descendi in hortum nucum, ut viderem poma convallium, et inspicerem si floruisset vinea, et germinassent mala Punica.
verses.notes: Earlier, the bride said that her beloved had descended to his garden of aromatic plants. But now she descends to a different garden, one that is difficult to access (in a steep valley) to see what has grown.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">I did not understand. My soul was stirred up within me because of the chariots of Amminadab.</font>
verses.textLa: Nescivi: anima mea conturbavit me propter quadrigas Aminadab.
verses.notes: The bride does not understand the state of the vineyard that she is examining. This cannot be the groom who does not understand because the groom represents Christ, who is God. The quadrigas is a particular type of chariot, one with four horses, used in battle. The word ‘Nescivi’ literally means ‘I did not know’ (perfect tense), but here it is used to mean ‘I did not understand.’ She is troubled because of a lack of understanding, not a lack of knowledge.

verses.textEn: Chorus to Bride: <font color="#008800">Return, return, O Sulamitess. Return, return, so that we may consider you.</font>
verses.textLa: Revertere, revertere Sulamitis: Revertere, revertere, ut intueamur te.
verses.notes: The chorus of maidens wishes to meditate upon the beauty of the bride. They ask her to return from examining the nearly inaccessible garden. They still seek further knowledge of the bride and groom, because they will eventually mature and become married themselves.

verses.textEn: Chorus to Groom: <font color="#008800">What will you see in the Sulamitess, other than choruses of encampments?</font>
verses.textLa: Quid videbis in Sulamite, nisi choros castrorum?
verses.notes: The phrase ‘choros castrorum’ is obscure, with multiple possible meanings; the translation leaves it obscure, with multiple possible meanings.

verses.textEn: Chorus to Bride: <font color="#008800">How beautiful are your footsteps in shoes, O daughter of a ruler! The joints of your thighs are like jewels, which have been fabricated by the hand of an artist.</font>
verses.textLa: Quam pulchri sunt gressus tui in calceamentis, filia principis! Iuncturæ femorum tuorum, sicut monilia, quæ fabricata sunt manu artificis.
verses.notes: In a previous verse, the maidens asked the bride to return, so that they can meditate on her beauty. Now the maidens expresses their meditation on the beauty of the bride. This is not the groom speaking, because he has already extolled her in much the same words. The maidens ask the groom what else he sees in the bride, so that they can understand her even better.

verses.textEn: <font color="#008800">Your navel is a round bowl, never lacking in curvature. Your abdomen is like a bundle of wheat, surrounded with lilies.</font>
verses.textLa: Umbilicus tuus crater tornatilis, numquam indigens poculis. Venter tuus sicut acervus tritici, vallatus liliis.
verses.notes: The word ‘tornatilis’ refers to something smoothed (perhaps on a lathe); the word ‘crater’ is not so much a crater as a bowl. The word ‘poculis’ can refer to a drink or to a cup, but in this context it refers to the curves of the bride’s abdomen. The word ‘navel’ is used to represent the exposed abdomen; the sentence is not about the navel itself.

verses.textEn: <font color="#008800">Your two breasts are like two young twin does.</font>
verses.textLa: Duo ubera tua, sicut duo hinnuli gemelli capreæ.
verses.notes: See how the maidens now understand the beauty of the bride in a manner similar to the groom. They sought and achieved a deeper understanding of the bride.

verses.textEn: <font color="#008800">Your neck is like a tower of ivory. Your eyes like the fish ponds at Heshbon, which are at the entrance to the daughter of the multitude. Your nose is like the tower of Lebanon, which looks out toward Damascus.</font>
verses.textLa: Collum tuum sicut turris eburnea. Oculi tui sicut piscinæ in Hesebon, quæ sunt in porta filiæ multitudinis. Nasus tuus sicut turris Libani, quæ respicit contra Damascum.
verses.notes: Cities are sometimes referred to as ‘daughters,’ especially if it is a city related to another larger city, or if it is a set of cities in the same area. The daughter of the multitude is probably a city. The maidens continue their discourse on the beauty of the bride, now that they have learned about her from the groom. The eyes are the entrance to the soul, which is profound, like a city with a multitude of peoples.

verses.textEn: <font color="#008800">Your head is like Carmel, and the hairs of your head are like the purple of the king, bound into pleats.</font>
verses.textLa: Caput tuum ut Carmelus: et comæ capitis tui, sicut purpura regis vincta canalibus.
verses.notes: The word ‘purpura’ refers to cloth died with the most expensive dye of the time, a purple dye favored by kings and the most wealthy. The word ‘regis’ is in the genitive singular, so the translation is ‘the purple of the king.’ It is not the king who is bound (‘vincta’), but the purple cloth of a king, which is bound into ‘canalibus,’ i.e. pleats. A cloth bound into pleats resembles hair bound into tresses or braids. Her hair resembles the most precious cloth of a king, bound into pleats.

verses.textEn: <font color="#008800">Most beloved one, how beautiful you are, and how graceful in delights!</font>
verses.textLa: Quam pulchra es, et quam decora charissima, in deliciis!
verses.notes: The maidens know how greatly loved the bride is by the groom. The text does not say ‘my beloved,’ as if the groom were speaking. This is the chorus continuing to show that they now understand the bride, who before was a dark mystery to them.

verses.textEn: <font color="#008800">Your stature is comparable to the palm tree, and your breasts to clusters of grapes.</font>
verses.textLa: Statura tua assimilata est palmæ, et ubera tua botris.
verses.notes: The maidens now compare her stature to the palm tree, whereas before the groom was compared to a palm tree.

verses.textEn: Groom: <font color="#CC0000">I said, I will ascend to the palm tree, and take hold of its fruit. And your breasts will be like clusters of grapes on the vine. And the fragrance of your mouth will be like apples.</font>
verses.textLa: Dixi: Ascendam in palmam, et apprehendam fructus eius: et erunt ubera tua sicut botri vineæ: et odor oris tui sicut malorum.
verses.notes: Dates are a common type of fruit from a palm tree. Now the groom is speaking about the bride, since he speaks about her breasts and since the person speaking is first person singular. The transition from the maidens speaking to the groom speaking is indicated by the introductory phrase: ‘I said....’

verses.textEn: Bride: <font color="#0000CC">Your throat is like the finest wine: wine worthy for my beloved to drink, and for his lips and teeth to contemplate.</font>
verses.textLa: Guttur tuum sicut vinum optimum, dignum dilecto meo ad potandum, labiisque et dentibus illius ad ruminandum.
verses.notes: She begins speaking directly to the groom, “Your throat,” then she continues speaking about him, but in the third person. This kind of compositional technique is common in Scripture. She calls him by the masculine ‘dilecto,’ so this is the bride speaking to the groom.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">I am for my beloved, and his turning is to me.</font>
verses.textLa: Ego dilecto meo, et ad me conversio eius.
verses.notes: The bride is devoted to the groom, who earlier in the poem she did not know as well, and as a result he turns toward her instead of fleeing from her.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">Approach, my beloved. Let us go out into the field; let us linger in the villages.</font>
verses.textLa: Veni dilecte mi, egrediamur in agrum, commoremur in villis.
verses.notes: The word ‘dilecto’ is in the masculine, so this is the bride still speaking. Notice that she switches back to speaking directly to him.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">Let us go up in the morning to the vineyards; let us see if the vineyard has flourished, if the flowers are ready to bear fruit, if the pomegranates have flourished. There I will give my breasts to you.</font>
verses.textLa: Mane surgamus ad vineas, videamus si floruit vinea, si flores fructus parturiunt, si floruerunt mala Punica: ibi dabo tibi ubera mea.
verses.notes: This is the bride speaking to the groom. Notice that she uses the first person plural, because now the two are more closely united than at the start of the Song.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">The mandrakes yield their fragrance. At our gates is every fruit. The new and the old, my beloved, I have kept for you.</font>
verses.textLa: Mandragoræ dederunt odorem. In portis nostris omnia poma: nova et vetera, dilecte mi, servavi tibi.
verses.notes: The bride is now ready to be married to the groom; she rejoices in their impending marriage.

verses.textEn: Bride to Groom: <font color="#0000CC">Who will give you to me as my brother, feeding from the breasts of my mother, so that I may discover you outside, and may kiss you, and so that now no one may despise me?</font>
verses.textLa: Quis mihi det te fratrem meum sugentem ubera matris meæ, ut inveniam te foris, et deosculer te, et iam me nemo despiciat?
verses.notes: The bride began not knowing the groom. Then she meditated on his exterior and interior qualities, reaching a better understanding of him. She became closer and closer to the groom, until now, finally, she is as close to him as two members of the same family.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">I will take hold of you and lead you into my mother’s house. There you will teach me, and I will give you a cup of spiced wine, and of new wine from my pomegranates.</font>
verses.textLa: Apprehendam te, et ducam in domum matris meæ: ibi me docebis, et dabo tibi poculum ex vino condito, et mustum malorum granatorum meorum.
verses.notes: The closeness of the bride and groom as reached the point where they can now live in the same house, as members of the same family. The bride is taught by the groom, who has the wisdom of Solomon.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">His left hand is under my head, and his right hand shall embrace me.</font>
verses.textLa: Læva eius sub capite meo, et dextera illius amplexabitur me.
verses.notes: The groom continues to love the bride, even as their love reaches new depths.

verses.textEn: Groom to Chorus: <font color="#CC0000">I bind you by oath, O daughters of Jerusalem, not to disturb or awaken the beloved, until she wills.</font>
verses.textLa: Adiuro vos filiæ Ierusalem, ne suscitetis, neque evigilare faciatis dilectam donec ipsa velit.
verses.notes: The groom again tells the maidens to respect the will of the bride.

verses.textEn: Chorus to Groom: <font color="#008800">Who is she, who ascends from the desert, flowing with delights, leaning upon her beloved?</font>
verses.textLa: Quæ est ista, quæ ascendit de deserto, deliciis affluens, innixa super dilectum suum?
verses.notes: Although the maidens continue to question the groom about his bride, their questions show an increased understanding of the bride. (Verses 5 and 6 in the CPDV are together verse 5 in the Latin; it was split into two verses because there are two different speakers.)

verses.textEn: Groom to Bride: <font color="#CC0000">Under the apple tree, I awakened you. There your mother was corrupted. There she who bore you was violated.</font>
verses.textLa: Sub arbore malo suscitavi te: ibi corrupta est mater tua, ibi violata est genitrix tua.
verses.notes: The groom notes that the bride’s mother went astray from faithfulness to her husband under an apple tree, and that the bride was awakened in that same place. He is concerned that his bride will go astray like her mother. So he continues with the next verse.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">Set me like a seal upon your heart, like a seal upon your arm. For love is strong, like death, and envy is enduring, like hell: their lamps are made of fire and flames.</font>
verses.textLa: Pone me ut signaculum super cor tuum, ut signaculum super brachium tuum: quia fortis est ut mors dilectio, dura sicut infernus æmulatio, lampades eius lampades ignis atque flammarum.
verses.notes: The previous sentence gives us the context, that of the groom’s concern for his bride’s faithfulness, lest she go astray. The groom is concerned that is bride may go astray because of worldly love for another, or by imitating other persons out of envy. This proverb-like expression is comparing ‘dilectio’ to death, so it cannot refer to the love between the groom and bride. Envy of other leads to imitating them, which can lead to Hell.

verses.textEn: <font color="#CC0000">A multitude of waters cannot extinguish love, nor can a river overwhelm it. If a man were to give all the substance of his house in exchange for love, he would despise it as nothing.</font>
verses.textLa: Aquæ multæ non potuerunt extinguere charitatem, nec flumina obruent illam: si dederit homo omnem substantiam domus suæ pro dilectione, quasi nihil despiciet eam.
verses.notes: A man who gives up everything for love counts all that he gave up as if it were nothing.

verses.textEn: Chorus: <font color="#008800">Our sister is little and has no breasts. What shall we do for our sister on the day when she is called upon?</font>
verses.textLa: Soror nostra parva, et ubera non habet. Quid faciemus sorori nostræ in die quando alloquenda est?
verses.notes: Now some members of the chorus of maidens are nearly ready to be married. They are maturing by learning from the groom and bride. But they are not yet fully mature.

verses.textEn: <font color="#008800">If she is a wall, let us build a rampart of silver upon it. If she is a door, let us join it together with boards of cedar.</font>
verses.textLa: Si murus est, ædificemus super eum propugnacula argentea: si ostium est, compingamus illud tabulis cedrinis.
verses.notes: The sister that the maidens are speaking of is not the bride, but the next of the maidens who is to be married in the near future. The maidens want to help her to be like the bride. They want to improve her, for her groom.

verses.textEn: Bride to Chorus: <font color="#0000CC">I am a wall, and my breasts are like towers, since, in his presence, I have become like one who has discovered peace.</font>
verses.textLa: Ego murus: et ubera mea sicut turris, ex quo facta sum coram eo quasi pacem reperiens.
verses.notes: The bride tells the maidens about her own experience of becoming ready for marriage. The statements that she is already a wall and her breasts are like towers mean that she is mature and ready for marriage. She tells the maidens how she became fully ready for marriage to the groom: by discovering peace in his presence.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">The peaceful one had a vineyard, in that which held the peoples. He handed it on to the caretakers; a man brought, in exchange for its fruit, a thousand pieces of silver.</font>
verses.textLa: Vinea fuit pacifico in ea, quæ habet populos: tradidit eam custodibus, vir affert pro fructu eius mille argenteos.
verses.notes: This translation is similar to the original Douai translation of the text. The bride is saying that she discovered peace in the presence of the groom. So the peaceful one is the groom, Solomon. The vineyard is located in that place which held an abundant number of different peoples. This phrasing in Hebrew is possibly the name of a region, so named because of the abundance of different peoples.

verses.textEn: Groom: <font color="#CC0000">My vineyard is before me. The thousand is for your peacefulness, and two hundred is for those who care for its fruit.</font>
verses.textLa: Vinea mea coram me est. Mille tui pacifici, et ducenti his, qui custodiunt fructus eius.
verses.notes: Now the groom has returned to his vineyard. The fruit of its peacefulness is valuable, and those who cared for it were faithful.

verses.textEn: Bride to Groom: <font color="#0000CC">Your friends are attentive to those who have been dwelling in the gardens. Cause me to heed your voice.</font>
verses.textLa: Quæ habitas in hortis, amici auscultant: fac me audire vocem tuam.
verses.notes: The subject, ‘Quae,’ is accusative plural feminine and the verb, ‘habitas,’ is the accusative plural feminine of the perfect passive participle, so the phrase ‘quae habitas in hortis’ is the object of the verb. The verb ‘auscultant’ takes an accusative object, not a dative one, despite the English phrasing of ‘listen to’ or ‘be attentive to.’ The groom’s friends (masculine plural, so these are the groom’s friends) are attentive to those maidens who have been spending time in the gardens. This is the bride speaking because she is commenting on what the groom said in the previous verse.

verses.textEn: <font color="#0000CC">Flee away, my beloved, and become like the doe and the young stag upon the mountains of aromatic plants.</font>
verses.textLa: Fuge dilecte mi, et assimilare capreæ, hinnuloque cervorum super montes aromatum.
verses.notes: The bride asks him to leave again, for now, knowing that they will soon enough be united forever.
